sections.narration: Welcome to our lesson on Uncle Tom's Cabin. The Power of Literature (1852). You'll experience this story through the eyes of Rebecca, age 14, Northern girl, 1852.

sections.section: Chapter 1: A Book That Changed America
sections.narration: I'm Rebecca, fourteen years old, living in Boston. Everyone in my family is reading Uncle Tom's Cabin by Harriet Beecher Stowe. The novel was published this year, 1852, and it's become the most talked-about book in America. Mother bought a copy last month.
visuals: Chapter title: A Book That Changed America
sections.key_takeaway: I'm Rebecca, fourteen years old, living in Boston.

sections.narration: The characters in Uncle Tom's Cabin feel real to me. Uncle Tom isn't just a name in a newspaper story about slavery—he's a person I know through Mrs. Stowe's words. Tom is deeply religious, kind, and noble.
visuals: Chapter title: The Characters Come Alive
sections.key_takeaway: The characters in Uncle Tom's Cabin feel real to me.

sections.narration: Uncle Tom's Cabin is everywhere in the North. It's selling faster than any book in American history—300,000 copies in the first year. Only the Bible sells more copies. People who've never thought much about slavery can't stop talking about it now.
visuals: Chapter title: Reaction in the North
sections.key_takeaway: Uncle Tom's Cabin is everywhere in the North.

sections.narration: The South is furious about Uncle Tom's Cabin. Southern newspapers call it lies, propaganda, and slander. They say Mrs. Stowe has never lived in the South and doesn't understand the institution of slavery.
sections.key_takeaway: The South is furious about Uncle Tom's Cabin.

sections.narration: It's extraordinary that a novel—a work of fiction—could have such political impact. But Uncle Tom's Cabin proves that stories can change the world. Mrs. Stowe didn't write a political treatise or economic argument.
visuals: Chapter title: The Power of Words
sections.key_takeaway: It's extraordinary that a novel—a work of fiction—could have such political impact.

sections.narration: In this lesson, we explored Uncle Tom's Cabin through 5 chapters. Key concepts included: Uncle Tom's Cabin, Harriet Beecher Stowe, Uncle Tom, Simon Legree.
